captions.text: We have coffee shops, we have game rooms, we have haunted houses.
I want to show you my students' hard work.  Let's go let's go!
Okay so I'm currently in the Japanese themed room,
as you can see behind me we have some takoyaki going on,
and I'm gonna have my own kimono and take a picture with it.
Ok I'm waiting in front of the game café, and as you can see
there is a huge lineup behind me.  Waaahhh!
I have to wait in line here!
Deebeedeebee dee!  Ohhh!  Got me again!
Ok the game's finished.  It was really difficult I got my butt kicked.
Ohh!  I got two lollipops which is great, oh!
And a flower balloon present, but beware the bunny games!
The bunny games are really hard!  Oh!!!
So we're enjoying my seng cream sandwich which is whipped cream inside of bread,
And here we have a white bun!  All the nutritious value you need in one meal:
Sugar, sugar, sugar, and some sugar!
My students are gonna be hyper!

comments.text:
In my country or at least in my high school, those event are held by 
student council. So student council will give the proposal to school , Of 
cos we need to do a proper proposal like what the purpose of the event and 
how we going to make it and of cos how we get the fund. I was one of the 
the student council member on my 2nd year. What I remember the events we 
held are
1. Valentine days : we invite kids from 3orphanage, and share some love. 
Weeks before we try to socialize our event to entire student, collect lots 
of loves from students that wants to share in any kind of way. Can be goods 
like books or toys or blanket, or event performance so they can be happy 
and enjoy the days.
2. we had 'pensi' which is almost the same with the one martina show in 
this video, but we open the gate to public and selling the ticket. So 
friends from other shool, parents or family can come.
3. Prom for the 3rd year. Yes the student council(normally 2nd year and1st 
year) prepared the party for the senior who will leave the school and start 
their whole new world out there.
4. And evry time student council needs money to support some clubs that 
needs to compete out there and of cos it needs money, we do some commercial 
event as in we held bazaar, make some booth, prepare some space. Student 
can rent the booth and sell food or merchandise like collector stuff, there 
is one student event rent a space to do exhibition of his stamp colection. 
In this event u can order some song and dedicates the song for someone 
else. It can be your crush, ur bffs, or fave teachers and the broadcast 
club will read your msg. Of cos u need to pay for it ;). Its almost the 
same like pensi.
5. We had sport festival. Each class have to send their delegates to join 
and competes in varies kind of sport. 

It was fun!! Damn i want to go back to those time.﻿

comments.author: Kailee Mathews

comments.text:
I love your videos! I've watched you for a long time and only now unearthed 
your old videos, which are just as awesome as the newer ones. I want to 
point out the folding of Martina's kimono. The traditional way to lay the 
sides is left over right. The video shows right over left, which is usually 
related to the dead. I don't know if you knew, but it's definitely a 
helpful thing to know. Again, love your videos!﻿
comments.author: AllyCharms

comments.text:
I wish my high school could be more like this.  The teacher-student 
relationships in S.K. seem to be closer and friendlier. At my school, the 
teachers aren't friendly and some don't even try engaging the students.  
It's awkward and it's one of the reasons why the American education system 
is going backwards.  Some students in the U.S. feel like school is the 
enemy esp. if they don't have a good teacher or don't have the resources to 
succeed.  Also, American students have a bad attitude towards learning in 
general.  I hope it will change someday.﻿

comments.author: Anthony J

comments.text:
You have to find something to work for, something that encourages you. Like 
take a challenging class, or join the band or a club. Can't find something 
you like? Make one! You need something to motivate you such as passing an 
AP test or learning a new instrument. 
Find people who support you and who make you feel good being yourself. 
Sounds cheesy and phrases and cliche, but it's so true!
Most importantly, remember that high school is ONLY 4 years of your ENTIRE 
life. In the long run, what happens in high school usually doesn't 
determine your entire future. They really make it seem like it might, but I 
reality things like not passing a class or being bullied, there's always a 
way around everything. Obviously, keep yourself out of trouble!! Young 
people always think they're indestructible, but we're not. Small mistakes 
and bumps may not hurt your entire life, but other things can. So be 
smarter than that! If it something feels wrong, then most likely it is. If 
you want to get anywhere in your life you have to make the right choices or 
at least understand that EVERYTHING has a consequence- some are good, some 
are bad. You have to think about the results of things before you do them 
because some things can really sting and close a lot of doors for you! Of 
course, like I said, if you mess up its not the end of the world. Just own 
your mistakes, don't be discouraged and work around it. It's going to be 
okay. :)
[ I hope I'm making sense...]

LISTEN TO YOUR ELDERS! And by elders, I mean teachers, and mentors and your 
parents. They DO know what they're taking about trust me. They've been 
through more than you have, not just in experience, but in education. They 
know what they're doing! You may not. So trust those who are there to help 
you. Find a teacher or counseled you can trust and they'll help you. Asking 
for help doesn't mean you're stupid. It's actually the smartest thing to 
do! Asking for help means that you want to do better and that you're trying 
to improve- and that means a lot! Successful people have NEVER made it on 
their own! They've always had some help to become who they are- so you need 
someone to help you through too, we all do~

High school is NOT about popularity, or being cool, or just having fun. It 
can be fun, but you have to remember the most important part of it. its 
about work! It's about preparing yourself. Because after those 4 short 
years, you're going to have your entire life left! And you have to be ready 
for a thise years you have left! That's why you can't waste your precious 
time. Find something to work towards. If college/ university isn't a 
possibility or your thing, there's no shame in going for a community 
college or vocational career. Or about going straight to work in something 
that you're passionate about. Success isn't always about money. Sometimes 
it's about simply doing something you love or doing something that make you 
and others feel good. There's lots of options out there, just be smart 
about it! ;)

I'm honestly not the greatest at giving advice. But as a high school senior 
with three weeks to graduation and a few months to going to dream college, 
I thought I'd share a few things that helped me get by. Don't lose hope. 
And if you do, talk to someone. There will always be someone out there who 
will listen. I understand, I've been the cynical skeptic teenager who 
thinks NO ONE UNDERSTANDS! But someone out there does. 

Be who you think you should be, and don't let other people put down your 
dreams. If you think you can do it, work for it and you can! But that's the 
big part- WORK. That's the only way you'll achieve anything- you have to 
put blood, sweat and tears into it, no matter what you do.
I hoped I helped even a little, and good luck in high school and beyond! ;)

- with love also from California, C ❤️

comments.text:
I'm pretty sure Korea has the same problem as Japan. Both have quite 
conservative government that shit on each other constantly. I'm not sure 
about Korea but after WW2 in Japan, the communists got a lot of support 
which made the Americans go "nope! Get the conservatives out of prison 
again!" and then they changed the system in a way that makes it really hard 
for a second party to get established which gives the Japanese the choice 
between weird conservatives and incompetent other options (because 
everybody with some political talent will join Abe's party). So you've got 
a government that is elected because it's the only acceptable option and 
not because the people agree with that party.

So you've got the Korean government in arresting Japanese journalists for 
no real reason and you've got the Japanese government being general dicks 
and denying 2nd or 3rd generation Koreans living in Japan citizenship which 
makes the dicks in Korea (the government) going even more crazy. Japan has 
a better relation to North Korea than South Korea for that reason. Because 
giant dicks don't get along with giant dicks and the Kim dynasty is more 
about sucking giant dicks and being a little (fat) dick.

And that's all we see in the news. And then we might also see the internet 
crazyness where Japanese people are racist dicks on 2chan (like we are on 
4chan) and the Koreans on whatever they use for such things.

But I don't think that the Japanese legitimately hate the Koreans or vice 
versa. It's more about government being shit and we in the west not seeing 
the full picture.

I wouldn't say awful lives, that's harsh. Yes, it's very strict and 
protective, but that doesn't mean they're all trapped and unhappy. We 
sometimes hold foreign countries to our standards and beliefs unconsciously 
putting their methods on a beneath our own. Every society is flawed. I'm 
American and much of the education is underfunded and understaffed, while 
Korea maybe is too active in shaping their future citizens. Instead of 
pointing out others flaws we should collaborate to find a balance.
